name: J. Edwin Orr
description:
J. Edwin Orr (1912 - 1987)
Listen to freely downloadable audio sermons by the speaker J. Edwin Orr in mp3 format. Brother Orr shared in an experience of revival in his youth as he traveled by faith and saw many powerful workings of God. After years of seeing personal revival and experiences in his ministry he studied the theme of historical revival to equip and teach the Church.

He published many books on the topic of subject of revival: "Can God?" "Full Surrender" and many others. He ministered cross-denoninationally in baptist, pentecostal, calvary chapel and in many other movements. He was also influential in the Campus Crusade for Christ organization.

sermons.title: Chapel of the Air - Interview with Dr. Orr (part 1)
sermons.description: In this interview, Dr. Orr speaks on the misunderstanding of the word "revival". Among other things, he discusses how revival is primarily aimed at the Church, as opposed to the lost. This is the only time I have heard Dr. Orr talk about his multiple PhD's; surely because he is asked in the interview. This interview displays the typical humility of this extremely knowledgeable and well-traveled individual who, though he is surely one of the foremost scholars on the subject of historic revival, offers correction to the modern church, but does so in a way that it is evident he is not trying to glorify himself. The late Dr. Orr expresses his desire in this interview to see revival again, and puts forth his opinion that he does not believe that future revival is reserved for the nation of Israel only.

sermons.title: Chapel of the Air - Interview with Dr. Orr (part 2)
sermons.description: Habakkuk 2:2, 2 Chronicles 7:14. Dr. Orr discusses how he believed that Satan was the main hindrance to people understanding revival, and though he was a revival scholar, his intent was not to increase knowledge on the subject for the sake of increasing knowledge, but rather to increase knowledge of revival to enable people to be subjects of revival. He also talks about areas of the world where he believed revival was currently happening, along with some of the mistakes that people have made after revival has occurred.  "I shudder to hear of people who claim to be filled with the Holy Spirit without any holiness of life." Dr. Orr talks about how after years of revival work he kept himself renewed. "Evan Roberts once said to me 'always pray for a vision to match your faith'."

sermons.title: Chapel of the Air - Interview with Dr. Orr (part 3)
sermons.description: An awesome question and answer session on revival; great quotes from Dr. Orr included in the interview: "...in one sense, if any congregation of God's people were to obey the light that they presently have, they would enjoy a measure of a revival."  "I think if the pastor is set against it there will be no revival, and the people may have to pray that either God would change his heart or remove him."  "Let the circle of the sin be the circle of confession." "...preach on sin, preach on the law."

sermons.title: Great Awakenings in American History Part 2
sermons.description: This special series was delivered at Lake Avenue Church in Pasadena, California in January of 1976. Orr gives a very informative overview of the beginnings of the third great awakening in American history (which is largely overlooked), starting around 1830, and went on for 12 years. He recounted the events preceding Charles Finney's famous revival in Rochester, New York, in that same year. He explained how 100,000 people were saved as a result of that revival when the town only had a population of 10,000. Orr also defused how false reports of people barking took place on the Frontier, and recounted how greatly the Hawaiian Islands were affected.

sermons.title: Great Awakenings in American History Part 3
sermons.description: This special series was delivered at Lake Avenue Church in Pasadena, California in January of 1976. Orr speaks on the awakening that started in 1857 with a prayer meeting in New York City with one man and ended up with the whole city packed out with prayer meetings in churches and auditoriums. It spread all over the nation, so glorious that D.L. Moody said at the end of his life (1899) that we wished to see that happen again in the Church. Orr relates how this awakening and conversions spread to Ireland and South Africa. He recounts an interesting event with Andrew Murray trying to bring order to a prayer meeting! Out of this revival came D. L. Moody, William Booth, Charles Spurgeon and others. The main theme is how through prayer people encountered the presence of the Lord. "In times of revival, sinners come running to the Lord," Orr said. Indeed they did!

sermons.title: Great Awakenings in American History Part 4
sermons.description: This special series was delivered at Lake Avenue Church in Pasadena, California in January of 1976. Orr speaks about the enthusiasm of the church at the turn of the 20th century to make it the "Christian Century." He details the events that brought about the revival in Wales in 1904 and its unofficial leader Evan Roberts, including many fascinating details of packed churches, declining crime in society, so much so that the police had to take up singing in quartets. From there he speaks of revivals that it spawned in China, Korea and the great Pentecostal outpouring at Azusa Street in 1906.

sermons.title: The Awakening of 1727 Onward
sermons.description: Preached at the Church on the Way in Van Nuys. Orr sets out on part 1 of describing what is known in America as "The Great Awakening" and its equivalent in Britain starting in 1727 with on fire Moravians.  The conditions in the world at that time that preceeded the awakening were deplorable and rotten--the gambling, drinking, slave trade, etc. as well as the once powerful Baptists, Congregationalists and Puritans that had lost their spirituality and power.  John Wesley, George Whitfield and Jonathan Edwards came into prominence around 1738 and Orr, in his typical fashion, paints a colorful description of what God was powerfully doing through these men of God.

sermons.title: The Awakening of 1792 Onward
sermons.description: Preached at the Church on the Way in Van Nuys. Orr describes the "unparallelled moral slump" that preceded the Second Great Awakening starting in 1792, so bad that churches were in fear that Christianity might be wiped out.  Jonathan Edwards and others called for "extraordinary prayer."  A union of churches began praying, with Boston seeing the beginnings of revival in 1792 and general national revival by 1798.  James McGrady asked his congregants to pray for him in 1799, and showers of blessing came in 1800 on the Kentucky frontier.  Out of this revival missionary societies began and colleges became training centers for young pastors and missionaries.

sermons.title: The Awakening of 1858 in America
sermons.description: Preached at the Church on the Way in Van Nuys. This great revival was termed "the event of the century" and in Orr's opinion one of the most cooperative periods in American history where the denominations acted as "one man".  It was spectacularly noted for extradordinary conversions and calls to service.  What led to this great awakening was a laymen's movement among churches for united prayer for God's outpouring of the Spirit.  Orr noted some interesting movements among the slaves and armies in the Civil War and the continued effects up until the death of Moody in 1899.

sermons.title: The Awakening of 1859 in Britain and Elsewhere
sermons.description: Preached at the Church on the Way in Van Nuys.  In this relatively short sermon, Orr explains how the revival in America caught fire starting in Ireland, and its effects even surpassing that in America.  Sinners were violently prostrated in what they called at that time "slain in the Spirit."  He chronicled how prayer meetings mushroomed all over Ireland, Scotland, Wales and England, and literally hundreds of thousands converted to Christ.  The fires of revival spread to the Scandanvian countries, Germany (which had 30 years of it) and the greatest outpourings ever to occur in Australia and South Africa.

sermons.description: Dr. Orr discusses the modern corruption of the word 'repent,' what the Scriptural meaning is, and discusses the Greek word that was translated into 'repent.' sermons.title: The Movements Between World Wars
sermons.description: This comprehensive series "History of Revival" was presented at the Church on the Way in Van Nuys, California in 1981. Although the revival tide was out between World War I and World War II in America, Britain and western Europe, God was doing great things on the frontiers.  Orr recounts revival in Ireland under Nicholson in the '20's which affected his life.  He recollects personal testimony of being in revivals in Norway, Canada and a localized one at Wheaton college.  Orr closes by highlighting great extended periods of revivals in China and East Africa that prepared the Church to stand under great times of persecution.

sermons.description: Brother Orr searches and explains exhaustively on what exactly the conscience is, what it does, and what can happen to it by ignoring it. "But somebody else said to me,'Your conscience teaches right from wrong.' Does it? Always? The Scripture doesn't teach that. The Scripture speaks of a pure conscience, it often speaks of a rotten conscience."
sermons.preacher_description:
J. Edwin Orr (1912 - 1987)
Listen to freely downloadable audio sermons by the speaker J. Edwin Orr in mp3 format. Brother Orr shared in an experience of revival in his youth as he traveled by faith and saw many powerful workings of God. After years of seeing personal revival and experiences in his ministry he studied the theme of historical revival to equip and teach the Church.

He published many books on the topic of subject of revival: "Can God?" "Full Surrender" and many others. He ministered cross-denoninationally in baptist, pentecostal, calvary chapel and in many other movements. He was also influential in the Campus Crusade for Christ organization.
